title: How to upload music on YouTube without getting copyright infringement - Quora

response.answer_text: In addition to the occasional song for my home videos, I actually had to seriously consider this in relation to my films.  Certainly have to own everything in a film. Youtube does have music available for free use on its site.  I suppose that's technically not uploading, but it's worth mentioning.  If you only plan to show your video on Youtube, or are only concerned with it having music there, it's usually a good idea to use their music.  They let you tweak just how loud it is, in relation to your video's audio. Certainly if it's music you created, you can use it.  If you have any musical ability, even to the point of doing something silly on a recorder, it actually will be pretty appropriate for most of what you see on Youtube, so I'd seriously consider this option.  It's fun! If there's music that's put into the public domain, as in absolutely free to do what you want with it, you can use that.  This doesn't mean the song itself being public domain.  The performance needs to be public domain.  So even though you might not have to reimburse J.S. Bach for his song, whoever played it sure as hell has the right to decide how their performance is used, and whether or not it requires compensation.  It's a separate consideration.  There's some stock music that comes with some audio/video-editing software (to get you started) that you certainly can use freely too. If the music has some license attached to it, you may be able to use it if your use falls within certain guidelines.  Creative commons music often works for Youtube, but read the specifics of the license it's posted with.  What I've often seen is specific requirements of "attribution", where you have to include specific text in the description of the Youtube video:  "Music by so and so".  The license might also restrict its use to non-commercial use, or whatever other conditions.  Creative commons music web sites might categorize the licenses for you, to help filter based on how you can use the music. Then there's the simple option of paying someone for a license. There's lots of web sites that have music you can preview and, by swiping your credit card, download immediately.  Or, of course, you can pay the copyright holder (musician or whoever owns the rights) the old-fashioned way.  Keep a copy of your receipt and license handy, in case someone challenges your right to use the music.  If someone does, and you have a license, you'd respond with this evidence. Hard to find anything you like?  You can find someone to compose the music!  For Youtube, keep in mind, you don't need high-end studio-sounding stuff.  Did you see the movie Juno?  Something simple usually works.  Maybe a little better than the recorder idea :)  What you might not realize is that a lot of musicians out there just want to get their name out there (via attribution), and if your video's for public distribution, they might give it their all and surprise you.  It'll also be timed and otherwise customized for your video, which puts it above 99.999% of what's out there.  The only problem is, if they're really not delivering, it's a bit awkward to pass, after they've done this for you for free :)

How can you upload music to YouTube and avoid copyright infringement? Don’t upload someone else’s music. Copyright infringement is copying or distributing someone else’s work without their permission. YouTube is a distribution method, so clearly that makes this an illegal act. Permission consists of: A specific use license, allowing you to use the music in a certain way, and then distribute that resulting work. For instance, I have a short film that has been doing well in film festivals. The music made for that film was granted under a use license allowing us to put it in our film and then post that film online and show it in film festivals. I have a contract granting that permission.General use licensing, such as Creative Commons. This covers any work posted online with a standing license that allowed anyone to use or share the work. Possibly there are some limitations on use, such as requiring attribution, or not using it in a commercial use (promotion for a product/service or directly selling the resulting work).Some try to apply the U.S. law of “fair use” to their inclusion of music to a video. That almost never works. Fair use requires the use to fit a narrow set of purposes: parody, review, academic use. And to use the minimum amount necessary. So using a whole song is not fair use. And unless your video is reviewing the song or changing the words in the song to become a parody, you really can’t fit the demands of fair use. Plus, most people in the world are not in the U.S., so fair use usually isn’t even an option.

In doing a search, I haven’t found a definitive, “one-stop shopping” answer to your question. Based on what I’ve found, a person posting famous songs on YouTube: may actually be violating copyright, but the copyright holder tacitly allows the use. Some indie musicians are more interested in their music becoming widely known than in preventing people from sharing it.may be violating copyright, but the copyright holder isn’t able to protect their copyright for some reason (financial, physical disability, legal dispute over copyright ownership, can’t prove copyright ownership, etc.).the copyright holder may not be a participant in YouTube’s Content ID (CID) program. YouTube automatically checks for violations on behalf of CID members. Other copyright holders may need to search for violators on their own.all famous songs aren’t covered by copyright. Content published before 1923, after 1922 and before 1978 without the (c) notice, and after 1922 and before 1964 with (c) notice but not renewed after 28 years is in the public domain. This content isn’t covered by copyright.The copyright holder may have given permission to a specific YouTuber to use their music.When creating your own YouTube videos, it’s best to use music provided by YouTube, stock music for which you have a license, or music known to be in the public domain. Even if you use music (other video content, images, etc.) that doesn’t require you to identify the source, I recommend keeping track of the source in case your use is challenged.

Safest way is to use music you know you are allowed to. This includes any music you have made yourself, music which you have bought the licence for, music which is in the public domain (both the composition AND the performance), or music that is specifically royalty free. Do not ever use someone else’s work (music, art, video, etc.) unless you know you have their specific permission to do so. Copyright is there for a reason and ignoring it is uncool. I am not a lawyer and this is not legal advice. If you have any serious questions or intend to publish something that you are not 100% certain is copyright infringement free, please contact an expert in copyright law for the country you live in.

How can I make a content with music on YouTube without copyright strike? You can get a copyright strike even if it’s an error. So if you are making the typical youtube video which nobody (that is to say, no more than a few thousand) sees, you will probably fly under the radar. If you want to technically be in the right, either use music in the public domain, or music that is offered without royalties, or music that you own, or music that you have paid to license, or else be making a video of a type that makes use of the music in a Fair Usage situation. 17 U.S. Code § 107 - Limitations on exclusive rights: Fair use JA - No legal advice is intended.

Use No-copyright or Royalty-free Music. There are a lot of YouTube channels and companies that provide this type of music. For example, Master Adit Music, NoCopyrightSounds, etc.Use YouTube’s Audio Library. This channel provides music from the YouTube’s Audio Library - Master Adit Music. You can find more songs by clicking here. But, don’t forget to see the Music Policies before using the songs.Get a license to use copyrighted song. There are a lot of ways to get licenses for copyrighted songs. They can be free or paid, depending on the Record Label. For example, if you join the Freedom Network, you get license to use a lot of Position Music tracks. Other websites include SoundStripe, JukeDeck, etc.

When you have about 1000 subscribers at least I would recommend using google and searching for a sponsor for a channel with 1000 subscribers. When your sponsored most all the sponsors have access to “epidemic sound” . You then can use whatever music you want on that site and it has like 250,000 music files. Your channel being sponsored it then won’t give you a copyright infringement and you’ll have tons of music and settings to match the music to the emotion that makes videos have a more enjoyable experience.

Posting original content is the best way to avoid copyright strikes on Youtube. Doing so prevents infringement issues from arising. However, Youtube has a “loophole” called fair use that allows others to post your video on their channel. The right to perform songs actually belongs to the individual song owners, and not to performers. Song owners are entitled to collect royalties for all public performances of their songs, which means that performers need licenses to perform them. Go to my Profile and you can find all about YouTube Monetization material there...

You can never just upload someone else's video and escape from copyright issues. However if your intention is not to earn money from someone else's hard work, there is an option in YouTube named Fair Use. Fair use is a legal doctrine that says you can reuse copyright-protected material under certain circumstances without getting permission from the copyright owner. More details in the link below https://www.youtube.com/yt/copyright/fair-use.html ThanksVinoth

You can either gain permission from the song owner, search for monetize-safe songs, pitch the song (have a higher risk though) or cover the song yourself. Of course, you’ll need to credit the creator of the song(s) (in the end of the video, or in the description, or you can link the song(s) that you used) regardless of what you choose.

Use music you have the right to use and distributeUse creative commons music.Use your own creations ( fully yours, a Madonna Song played by you with your guitar, Madonna still hold rights on the song and will claim it, that called composition claim.Use old classic music, that all rights are legally from no-one.

Use a different song that is not copyrighted. I use almost all copyrighted music, but the money goes to the writer and performer. I have never cared about making money from YouTube. It’s my hobby. I’m earning money for classic country artists, because they are paid for views. if you are going to use someones copyrighted video or audio then you will definitely going to face copyright issues. but you can opt for fair use on YouTube. it is a option which indicates that your main motive is not earning money. giving a warm thanks to original creator in description is also a good thing that you can do.

First thing: read everything about copyright that applies to your country. Read carefully. Then apply. Many YouTube videos actually violate copyrights. Do not come up with an excuse like “but they also do…” That does not make it safe. It only shows you disrespecting the law. Read. Apply. Good luck!

Easy, make your own music. You'll own what you create by default, and therefore matters of permission are moot. Any other strategy carries no absolute guarantee without securing permission from the rightsholder, with the possible exception of using brief clips and samples as part of a critique or review.

response.answer_text: You need legislative changes. These changes need to make sure that creating social media community guidelines would no longer be as easy as before. Copyright laws should no longer be used to punish innocent people.
You know there is a thing called The youtube audio library there is where you can use most of the song for free but some of them you must credit the artist in the description.
Upload original music that you created yourself, or music considered in the public domain.
Use music that you have either created yourself, downloaded from the YouTube, otherwise received permission to use, or is in the public domain.
You just have to credit the original author properly. Then you would not get copyright infringement and also you can not get commercial benefit from that video.
Create the music entirely yourself, and/or obtain permission for anyone else’s work that you wish to use.
Get permission from the ownerRemake the music (don’t claim ownership though)Don’t use other’s music in the first place
You can upload the audio without getting a strike, but the video with get you a copyright strike. Lyric videos will only get ads on them.
